response: Ipswich Town won the cup final against AZ Alkmaar in 2016, with Butcher playing a key role. He also participated in a charity cycling event to raise money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Severe storms caused major flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles, with the council facing a £508,000 contribution towards repairs under the Bellwin Scheme. 240 pieces of work, including 114 major projects, must be undertaken to repair the damage.

Thomas Cook Airlines will operate a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer, using an Airbus A330 fleet. The airline has also added an additional flight to Tunisia, with three weekly flights available in the summer of 2015.

The 2016 European Championship draw is scheduled for December 12, with the seedings based on Uefa's national team coefficient rankings. The top seeds include Spain, France, Germany, Portugal, and Belgium. The play-off draw will take place on Sunday, with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary as seeds, and the Republic of Ireland, Denmark, Norway, and Slovenia as possible opponents.

Damon Smith denied making or possessing an explosive substance with intent to endanger life, but admitted to perpetrating a bomb hoax. He told police he built a device to produce smoke, but added ball bearings to make it look like a real bomb. The device was found by passengers and handed to a driver, who realized it contained wires and a clock. Smith has Asperger's syndrome and is interested in guns and weapons. He told police he had been brought up Christian but was interested in Islam. The trial continues.

The Mansfield District Council has approved a £250m development scheme, despite receiving over 140 objections. The scheme includes 1,700 homes, a new school, cemetery, community center, and park. The planning committee voted in favor of the scheme with the chairman having the casting vote. Protesters shouted "shame" as the decision was made. The developers claim the scheme will bring 4,000 jobs to the local economy. However, concerns over countryside and habitat loss, congestion, and the ability to deliver the promised benefits remain.
The UN reports that Europe has the highest rate of discarded fish, with nearly a quarter of catches being thrown back overboard dead due to unwanted species.

HP acquired WebOS from Palm in 2011 for $1.2bn. LG acquired WebOS from HP in 2013 for use in smart TVs. HP retains patents and technology for web-based services. The acquisition was driven by LG's need to differentiate through software-based innovation in user experience.

Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy criticized his team for conceding a late goal in a pre-season friendly against U, calling it "garbage" and "unforgiveable." He expressed frustration with his team's tendency to concede late goals, citing examples from last season in the Championship.

Jane Austen's sight deteriorated significantly, possibly due to accidental arsenic poisoning from medication, according to tests on three pairs of her glasses at the British Library. The glasses, which increased in strength over time, suggest she would have had difficulty reading and writing towards the end of her life.

Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby announced plans to fix Easter Sunday on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, following a meeting with church leaders. The current variable date, based on the moon's cycle, has been in place since the 10th century. Welby hopes the change will happen within 5-10 years, but acknowledges past attempts have been unsuccessful.

Ulster Bank's monthly survey of firms in Northern Ireland showed a modest decline in business conditions in April, with output and new orders decreasing. Manufacturing was a bright spot, with growth in output and new orders. Despite the decline, companies are continuing to hire staff. The construction sector saw a large fall in business activity. The detail of the new Conservative government's fiscal plans and economic policies will affect all sectors of the economy.

UKIP's high street shop in Penarth, Wales has faced opposition since its November opening. The party has invited anarchist allies to target posters of Mr. Farage and John Rees-Evans with eggs, but according to a UKIP spokesman, no eggs have been thrown.
Theatre Royal in Windsor, UK, was forced to evacuate during the opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors" due to flash flooding. The auditorium was dried out and the show resumed the following night.

Fiji has a history of political upheaval, including coups and tension between indigenous Fijians and ethnic Indians. Frank Bainimarama, an indigenous Fijian, was sworn in as prime minister in 2014 after seizing power in a military coup. The country has a diverse population and a president elected by parliament. The government controls media through the Media Decree, leading to self-censorship. Key dates include independence from Britain in 1970 and the election of the first ethnic Indian prime minister in 1999.

The Bihar state government in India took measures to curb cheating in exams after a video of a student, Ruby Rai, went viral where she said political science was about cooking. Despite the measures, the pass rate was low, but Ruby and 12 other students will have to retake the exam due to suspicions of cheating.

Protesters in Manchester, England set up a new camp after being evicted from St Peter's Square. The demonstrators are drawing attention to the lack of temporary housing and the plight of homeless people. The council has criticized the camp for inappropriate behavior and vandalism, and the cost of the camp has exceeded £88,000. The homelessness service has provided support and advice to camp members.

Two pieces of debris found in Mozambique have been identified as coming from the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. The debris was found by members of the public and was consistent with drift modeling of how debris from the plane may have been carried by ocean currents. The search for the plane continues, with 25,000 sq km of ocean still to be searched.

The RMT union is planning two more days of strike action against ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour urges the transport minister to meet with both sides to end the stalemate. Transport Scotland says the minister has already engaged with both sides and encourages them to find a solution through meaningful discussion. The RMT opposes driver-only trains, while ScotRail claims they are safe and efficient. Passengers are advised to check for updates before traveling.

The Cavaliers lost the first two games against the Warriors, but Kyrie Irving scored 30 points to help them win game three. The Warriors' coach, Steve Kerr, said his team wasn't ready to play, and LeBron James credited his teammates for encouraging him to be aggressive.

The Official Charts Company reports that Ellie Goulding's "Burn" has taken the number one spot on the UK singles chart, selling 117,000 copies and surpassing Avicii's "Wake Me Up" by 40,000 copies. Lady Gaga's "Applause" entered the chart at five, while Miley Cyrus's "We Can't Stop" fell two places to number three. In the album chart, Richard and Adam Johnson's "The Impossible Dream" held onto the top spot for a third week, tied with Justin Timberlake's "The 20/20 Experience" for the most consecutive weeks at number one this year.

Highland Council avoided £1.3m in planned cuts, but will still make savings through sickness absence policy and schools energy incentives. A proposal to cut senior councillors' pay was defeated, and the council will not cut funding for vulnerable people. The council will make savings in other areas, such as street cleansing and women's aid groups, due to the council tax freeze.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn read a Bible passage that included verses condemning homosexuality during a worship service at HMP Littlehey in 2014. He was told that gay prisoners had complained, and he was later dismissed from his volunteer role leading chapel services. Trayhorn alleges he was unfairly dismissed and his case against the secretary of state for justice continues.

The UK Home Office has been criticized for its handling of "overstayers" - foreign nationals refused leave to stay in the country. The independent inspector of immigration, John Vine, found that the Home Office's contract with private outsourcing group Capita led to significant inaccuracies in the classification of migration refusal records, resulting in an overestimation of the number of "overstayers" who had departed the UK. Vine called for improvements in the Home Office's ability to monitor and prioritize the immigration enforcement caseload. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire agreed to take forward the report's recommendations, emphasizing that the government's changes have had a positive impact and need to be judged over time.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau, Wales will close due to a lack of permanent dentists. The town's other practice is private. The NHS practice has been unable to recruit a permanent dentist for two years. The deputy mayor and clinical director of My Dentist have expressed concern about the shortage of dentists in rural areas. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board will re-commission dental services, but there may be a gap in service. Temporary solutions include short-term support from nearby practices and a dental out-of-hours clinic. The Welsh Government expects the health board to continue improving access to NHS primary care dental services.

Liam Day, 26, went missing while climbing near Durlston Country Park in Southampton. An extensive search by police, coastguard, and rescue teams has been suspended. His partner, Emily Brown, believes he will not return. Climbing equipment was found west of Anvil Point. Police are asking anyone with information to come forward.

Jim McGuinness, manager of the Donegal football team, is preparing his team to face the defending champions in the All-Ireland semi-final. He emphasizes the importance of trusting his players to execute their roles and make decisions on the field. Despite being considered underdogs, McGuinness is focused on his team's preparation and performance rather than external expectations.

According to a report by High Fliers, around 1,000 graduates declined job offers in 2015, leaving employers searching for replacements. Despite this, the number of graduates hired rose 3.3% and starting salaries remained at around £30,000. Top employers are fighting over the best candidates, with many receiving multiple offers. Graduates are becoming increasingly choosy about the employers they join.

A man was injured when he fell onto the tracks at Twickenham Station after England's World Cup game. He suffered head and leg injuries and was taken to the hospital. The train had been slowing down, and it is unclear how he fell. Services were suspended but later resumed.

Malta is a small island nation located south of Sicily, with a rich history of colonial control and cultural influences. It has been occupied by various empires, including the Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and the British. Malta gained independence from Britain in 1964 and has since developed into a popular tourist destination and a leading center for container and freight transhipment. The country has a population of 419,000 and a total area of 316 sq km. The official languages are Maltese and English, and the major religion is Christianity. The president is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, and the prime minister is Joseph Muscat. Malta has a long history of political affiliations with various newspapers and broadcasters. Some key dates in Malta's history include 1814, when it became a crown colony of the British Empire, 1939-1945, when it suffered heavy bombing during World War II, 1964, when it gained full independence, 1974, when it became a republic, 2004, when it joined the European Union, and 2008, when it adopted the euro.

Demolition, a tragicomedy directed by Jean-Marc Vallee, premiered at TIFF. The film stars Jake Gyllenhaal as a successful investment banker who must rebuild his life after his wife's death. Vallee praised Gyllenhaal's performance, saying he went everywhere and tried everything. The film brings Vallee back to TIFF for a third consecutive year.

The Belfast Telegraph reports on a boy who survived a petrol bomb attack and is now struggling with scars from his surgery. The Irish News covers a controversial grant scheme for Orange Halls and reports on a boy fighting epilepsy in the US. The paper also covers reaction to President Trump's travel ban and a possible prosecution decision in the Kingsmills massacre case.

Action on Hearing Loss surveyed 1,000 adults and found that 33% would ignore safe volume levels on their music players, increasing their risk of tinnitus. DJ Paul Oakenfold supports the campaign and urges people to wear ear defenders to gigs and use noise-cancelling headphones to protect their hearing. The poll also found that 1 in 10 people are affected by tinnitus, and 1 in 5 would not take steps to protect their hearing.

France won the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup, with Richard Gasquet and Coco Vandeweghe winning their respective matches. The deciding doubles match was won by Gasquet and Kristina Mladenovic, denying the United States a seventh title.

Australia's coach, Eddie Jones, discusses his team's upcoming match against Ireland at Twickenham, saying that he can feel the long-seated rivalry towards England. He also talks about his plans for Leicester centre Manu Tuilagi's future in the 12 shirt and praises his team's commitment and independence.

In Scotland, the Scottish Ambulance Service received around 12,000 calls related to excessive alcohol consumption in a six-month period, with the majority of calls coming from the Glasgow and Clyde area. The service stated that alcohol has a significant impact on its operations and that its staff often face challenges when responding to patients who are intoxicated. The Tory health spokesman, Jackson Carlaw, emphasized the need for personal responsibility in addressing the issue, while Public Health Minister Maureen Watt highlighted the importance of responsible drinking to alleviate pressure on emergency services.

Northern Ireland's economic inactivity rate is 27%, with 11 projects launched to address the issue through voluntary participation of individuals with work-limiting health conditions, disabilities, lone parents, and caring commitments. The strategy aims to increase employment levels above the UK average by 2030.

Trump criticized McCain, saying he was only considered a hero because he was a POW. He later clarified his remarks, but did not apologize. McCain's daughter Meghan tweeted that she was disgusted. Trump's rivals for the nomination attacked him, and analysts predict his appeal will wane as the contest develops.

W.P. Kinsella, a renowned Canadian author, passed away on Friday, assisted by a doctor, in a legal practice in Canada. He was best known for his novel "Shoeless Joe," which was adapted into the film "Field of Dreams." Kinsella published over 30 works and won the Order of Canada. After a head injury, he lost interest in writing fiction but later resumed and his final work is set to be released next year.

Máiría Cahill, a former IRA abuse victim, won a by-election in Northern Ireland's Senate, receiving 122 of 188 valid votes. She apologized for her past involvement with a dissident republican group and vowed to use her position to support abuse victims and young jobseekers.

The NSPCC's ChildLine has launched a campaign to address the concern of 12 to 13-year-olds who feel they are addicted to pornography. Boys in Cardiff and Prestatyn have contacted the charity, expressing worry about their exposure to porn and its impact on their views of girls and relationships. A UK-wide poll found 20% of children have seen upsetting or shocking pornographic images. The charity emphasizes the need for open conversation and support to address this issue.

Mariner Street car park will be replaced with a 725-bedroom student block, including a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. The 22-storey tower will be the second tallest building in Swansea, with construction expected to start this year and finish by summer 2018. The project aims to address the growing need for student accommodation in Swansea and support the city's regeneration efforts.

Floods in Queensland and New South Wales, Australia, have partially submerged towns and caused damage. Residents have been using surfboards to navigate flooded streets, and emergency warnings have been issued. Businesses and homes have been inundated, and roads and trees have been washed away. The storm system has now moved out to sea, but the damage bill is still unknown.

American Airlines experienced a software glitch on their iPads used by pilots and co-pilots for viewing flight plans, causing some flights to return to the gate for a wi-fi connection to fix the issue. The airline apologized for the inconvenience and is investigating the cause. The use of iPads and electronic flight bags is becoming common among airlines to save fuel and improve efficiency.

Girish Pote was convicted of murdering his wife Madhuvanti Pathak in 2013. He chopped her body into pieces and called relatives to confess. The Thane district court judge sentenced him to life in prison, citing the gruesome nature of the crime. Pathak held a French passport and the couple had a two-year-old son. Police stated that Pote attacked his wife with a knife and the couple fought over money and her desire to return to France.

Bradford Council plans to implement a clockwise one-way gyratory system on East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to alleviate growing congestion. The plans will be displayed at the Airedale shopping centre on June 11 and 13 for public viewing.

Thorpe, 23, has made 7 appearances for the Millers this season, but hasn't played since the 5-2 defeat by Ipswich on Nov 7. He could make his Bradford debut against Millwall on Saturday. The Bantams are currently 7th in League One, outside the play-offs on goal difference.

A radio presenter pranked Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy by pretending to be Carles Puigdemont, the Catalan leader, and arranged a meeting. Rajoy agreed but was later told it was a joke. He took it well but expressed disappointment. This is not the first time a high-profile figure has fallen for a prank call.

Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee questioned the £1 pay rate for immigration detainees who have committed no crime. Baroness Williams of Trafford replied that the work is voluntary and helps meet recreational and intellectual needs. Labour frontbencher Lord Rosser argued that the government saves £300,000 per month by using detainees at £1 per hour instead of minimum wage employees. Baroness Williams insisted that the work is not about supplementing contractors and that the detainees benefit from the paid activities. The question of who benefits from the scheme remains unclear.

The Walter Scott Prize shortlist has been announced, featuring seven novels that offer readers a unique perspective on historical events. The judges praised the variety of the longlist and the ability of the shortlisted novels to provide a "visceral connection" with their characters. The winner will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in June.

England and Bangladesh are playing a Test match, with Bangladesh needing 33 runs to win but only having two wickets left. The game has been exciting and closely contested, with both teams showing skill and character. The pitch has turned more than expected, and there have been a record number of decisions reviewed. England's Stuart Broad spoke to BBC Test Match Special about the game, saying that it has been a thrilling contest and that both teams have played well. The outcome is still uncertain, and the teams will resume play tomorrow.

UCU Scotland members voted to strike over job security concerns at the University of Aberdeen's medical school. The union claims the process has been discriminatory as all four staff members affected are of Asian ethnic origin. The university denies this and says alternative employment has been offered to the staff members.

Jay Liptrot, 43, owned the property where 5 people died in a fire in Prestatyn, Denbighshire in 2012. Lee-Ann Shiers, her partner, son, nephew, and niece died in the fire. Mr. Liptrot did not enter a plea and will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.
A 34-year-old man was arrested and later released pending further inquiries after a disgraceful incident at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay, described as such by Police Scotland.

The "Read On. Get On." report highlights the importance of children's reading skills, stating that those who fall behind may face negative consequences throughout their lives. The coalition behind the report aims to improve children's reading abilities, particularly among those living in poverty. They encourage parents to read to their young children daily and provide resources for families to improve reading skills. The report also notes that children are now more likely to read text messages and digital content, rather than traditional books.

The Belfast Giants have signed Martinelli for another season. He joins Mark Garside in committing to the team. Both players have a history of success with the Giants and are excited to continue playing together.

Rasmus Barlow, 16, was reported missing and later found dead. The police have ruled out suspicious circumstances and are preparing a file for the coroner's office. Family liaison officers are supporting the teenager's family.

Regina Hungerford, a teacher, was found guilty of unacceptable conduct by the Education Workforce Council after she lost her temper and slammed a notebook on a student's desk. The council ruled that she had made physical contact with the student, which put at risk the public trust in the profession and fell short of the expected standards of a registered teacher.

Big brands and celebrities are using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou to promote their products and services, while some charities are using it to raise awareness. The British Museum is hosting an actual Star Wars exhibit, and Heathrow Airport has tweeted a funny joke featuring Star Wars spaceships.

Retired generals and admirals support Trump's bid for commander-in-chief, citing his temperament and ability to strengthen the military. Trump has been criticized for his treatment of veterans and military families, but has made support for the military a central issue in his campaign.

The 21-year-old player joined the Tykes from QPR after their promotion to the Championship, but made only seven league appearances. He had a brief loan spell at Colchester and signed a one-year contract with a 12-month option at John McGreal's team.

Philip Pullman's new trilogy, The Book of Dust, will be released starting in October 2017, with the first novel's title yet to be announced. The series will follow Lyra Belacqua's story from infancy to age 20, and is a continuation of the His Dark Materials series, which sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

The American Red Cross apologized for a racist pool safety poster they produced, which depicted more black children being "not cool" while white children were behaving sensibly. The poster has been removed from their website and will no longer be printed. The organization is committed to diversity and inclusion in all that they do.

Winkelman, the chairman of Milton Keynes Dons, expressed his support for manager Karl Robinson, citing his drive and understanding of the club. Despite relegation from the Championship, Winkelman believes Robinson is the right man for the job and plans to continue investing in him. Both men have acknowledged mistakes were made in recruitment, but are looking forward to the challenge of League One next season.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan have been named honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Cosmo has starred in films such as Braveheart, while Gillan has turned to directing after previously starring in Dr. Who. EIFF artistic director Mark Adams expressed excitement about the addition of the two Scottish luminaries to the festival's honorary patrons. Both Cosmo and Gillan expressed their gratitude and privilege at being selected for the honor.

Danny Rose, a left-back for Tottenham, made comments in an interview saying that he and his teammates are underpaid and that the team needs to sign well-known players. He has since apologized for his comments, citing that they were ill-judged. Rose will miss the game against Newcastle due to a knee injury, but Kieran Trippier's ankle injury is not as severe as initially thought.

Vanessa Vanakorn, a British violinist who competed for Thailand in the Sochi Winter Olympics, was banned from skiing for two years due to allegations of manipulating results to ensure her qualification. She and five officials were punished following an investigation, and the Court of Arbitration for Sport will now consider her appeal.

Macclesfield Town won 1-0 against Eastleigh. Rhys Browne scored the only goal in the 7th minute. The game had few chances for both sides, with Eastleigh nearly equalizing in the 70th minute, but the header hit the post.

Warner Bros TV is struggling to reach agreements with the main cast of "The Big Bang Theory" over salaries, potentially delaying production. The cast, including Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Simon Helberg, and Kunal Nayyar, are seeking higher pay, with some aiming for $1 million per episode. The show has been extended for three more seasons and the cast's current salaries are $325,000 per episode.

Alexander Worth died in a car crash on an access road in North Warnborough. Matthew Cobden, 38, appeared in court and confirmed his identity. Alexander, from Kings Worthy, died in August and Mr. Cobden was taken to the hospital with serious injuries. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court.

Refugees spoke at a gathering in Queen Street, calling for action. The Welsh Refugee Council welcomed the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians. Demonstrations were held in Swansea and Caernarfon. The Methodist minister called it the most serious human-made disaster of our time. The UK will accept up to 20,000 people from Syrian camps, with priority given to vulnerable children. A Wales summit on the refugee crisis will be held next week. Local authorities are willing to help but need assistance with costs.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, a former hitman for Pablo Escobar, was released from prison after 20 years, sparking controversy in Colombia. Velasquez confessed to killing 300 people and claimed involvement in up to 3,000 deaths, but he also testified against a former justice minister convicted of ordering a political assassination. Velasquez's early release has divided opinions, with some arguing he hasn't paid for all his crimes, while others believe he deserves a second chance.

Kurt Gidley, a rugby league player for the Warrington Wolves, wore a camera during a game to give viewers a unique perspective. The camera was removed at half-time due to technical issues, and the team's coach, Tony Smith, said it was not an excuse for their loss. Sky Sports, the broadcaster, will continue experimenting with the technology.

Police were called to a care home in Campbeltown, Scotland, where a 76-year-old woman was allegedly sexually assaulted. An 82-year-old man is under investigation and the Care Inspectorate is working closely with Police Scotland to monitor the situation. The safety and well-being of care home residents is a top priority. Anyone with concerns can contact the Care Inspectorate's helpline.

Des McDaid, a survivor of child abuse, shared his experiences with the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry. He was sent from Northern Ireland to Australia as a child migrant and was sexually abused by older boys, members of the Christian Brothers religious order, and a lay teacher. He also traced his mother and has reconnected with her. The inquiry is examining the extent of child abuse in religious and state-run institutions in NI from 1922 to 1995.

Stan Wawrinka defeated Kyle Edmund in a thrilling match, advancing to the semi-finals where he will face Kei Nishikori. Milos Raonic also progressed to the last four, defeating Rafael Nadal, and will play Grigor Dimitrov. Aljaz Bedene was knocked out in the quarter-finals by Benoit Paire.

U2's tour plans have been disrupted due to the hospitalization of their lead singer, Bono. He is expected to stay in a Munich clinic for several days and then return to Ireland to recuperate. The band's US tour date on June 3 has been postponed, and their Glastonbury appearance may be in doubt. Further information about the impact on other tour dates will be announced later.

A small plane crashed between Abergavenny and Raglan in Wales, injuring two passengers and the pilot, who were taken to hospital. Officials alerted air accident authorities, and firefighters contained a fuel leak from the aircraft, which led to a road closure.

Angela Scott will become the new chief executive of Aberdeen City Council in July, replacing Valerie Watts. Scott is currently the council's director of corporate governance and has impressed in her role. She has been chosen for her financial expertise, drive, and leadership abilities. The salary for the position

Manchester United's full-back options are limited due to injuries, with Luke Shaw, Marcos Rojo, Ashley Young, Antonio Valencia, and Phil Jones out. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love are the only fit full-backs, and Van Gaal may have to use a young player or someone from the youth team.

Kenneth Harper was convicted of sex crimes, assault, and reckless behavior, but his convictions for two rape charges were later quashed due to a lack of "extraordinary features" connecting the two incidents, which occurred eight years apart. He was given a three-year sentence for the remaining offenses.

Jim Broadbent is set to star as Tommy Butler in The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale, a drama that will explore the story of the infamous heist from the perspective of the police. Broadbent is excited to play the role of Butler, a respected and skilled detective who led the investigation into the robbery. The drama is set to air later this year and is executive produced and written by Chris Chibnall.

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was attacked by a group of girls in Central Park in Peterborough, Cambridgeshire. The victim's mother posted a video of the brawl on social media to find out who was responsible. Police are investigating the incident.

The Maccabees scored their first number one album with Marks To Prove It, narrowly beating Lianne La Havas' Blood. Cilla Black's album and single re-entered the charts following her death. One Direction released a new single, Drag Me Down, and Calvin Harris and Disciples' How Deep Is Your Love climbed to number two. The top five albums and singles are listed.

One Direction continues as a four-piece band after Zayn Malik's departure, with Liam Payne thanking fans for their support. The band continues their tour, starting the European leg in Cardiff, while Zayn Malik works on a solo album with producer Naughty Boy.

Police Scotland is investigating a leak of sensitive information on social media, including witnesses' names and details of an alleged gun hit. Inquiries are ongoing to determine the full circumstances surrounding the incident.

Steven Flynn broke into St Johnstone's stadium with a crowbar to find money for drug debts. Police didn't realize there was a break-in until a cleaner found rummaged cupboards and a stolen charity box. Flynn was jailed for 16 months.

Nigel Farage visited Sleaford to support UKIP candidate Victoria Ayling in the upcoming by-election. A poster with a spelling error was seen behind him, with the letter "n" in "Hykeham" misspelled. The error was pointed out on social media, but UKIP has not responded to the BBC's inquiry. The by-election takes place on Thursday.

Blair Henderson scored for the hosts after 24 seconds, followed by a missed opportunity by Moses Olanrewaju. Brian Martin was sent off for handling in the area, but Sean Dickson missed the resulting penalty, leaving the hosts with a 1-0 lead.

Fiona Barnes was jailed for 15 months for stealing £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre and trying to cover her tracks by faking documents. She was ordered to pay back £1 at a Proceeds of Crime hearing, which the centre's deputy manager called "a complete insult" given the severity of the theft.

Adam El-Abd, a 31-year-old defender, has joined Shrewsbury Town after being released by Bristol City. He has previously played for Brighton and had loan spells with several clubs. He joins Joe Riley, another defender, in Shropshire as the team's manager, Micky Mellon, rebuilds his squad for the new League One campaign.

Jones believes England needs 8-9 leaders to win the World Cup. He says the team has a small, good group but lacks consistent leaders. The coaches are working on individual leadership plans for players. Hartley will captain the side in the Six Nations, with Farrell as a possible replacement.

Chris Rogers, a former Australian Test cricketer, has signed with Somerset for the upcoming County Championship season. The team's director of cricket, Andy Maynard, is thrilled with the signing, calling Rogers a "marquee player" and a "great acquisition." Rogers will bat at number three and is expected to provide stability and experience to the team's batting lineup. Maynard believes that Rogers' experience and determination will be valuable assets to the team, particularly in supporting the opening duo of Marcus Trescothick and Tom Abell.

A Range Rover crashed into a house on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing significant damage and displacing two people. No one was injured, but an investigation has begun and police are seeking witnesses.

Work to demolish a building on Kingsway began in October 2015 and was expected to take six months. However, the outer structure still stands due to unexpected amounts of asbestos. The council purchased the site as part of plans to revitalize the area into a business district. Internal works are complete, and scaffolding is in place for exterior demolition. The project is now expected to finish by spring.

Blackpool manager Gary Bowyer has called for the introduction of goal-line technology in the Championship after a controversial goal was awarded against his team during a 2-1 loss to Fulham. Bowyer believes the technology would improve the game and give teams the chance to win games they deserve to win.

Leicester City have signed 19-year-old player Bartosz Kapustka for £7.5m on a five-year deal. He impressed at Euro 2016 and has joined the team in Stockholm before their friendly match against Barcelona. This is City manager Claudio Ranieri's fifth summer signing.

The Burrell Collection will close for redevelopment and reopen in 2020 with new exhibition space and energy-efficient features. The collection will be accessible during the closure through changing displays at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery, starting with an exhibition of works by the Glasgow Boys.

Hundreds of farmers supplying chickens to Moy Park are recipients of the heating subsidy. The company met with officials to find a solution to secure the Northern Ireland RHI scheme within budget. Moy Park advocates for responsible heat use and has extensive experience in benchmarked energy use in the poultry industry. The Finance Minister has raised concerns over the scheme's operation.

Police are investigating the death of a man whose body was found in a field near Belsyde Avenue on Saturday. They are working to identify the man and determine his cause of death through a post-mortem examination.

Ipswich Town won the cup final against AZ Alkmaar in 2016, with Butcher playing a key role in the team's success. To celebrate the victory, Butcher joined a charity cycling team that raised money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy by cycling 260 miles to Holland and back.

Severe storms caused major flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles, with the full cost of repairs yet to be calculated. The council will receive support under the Bellwin Scheme but must contribute £508,000. 240 pieces of work, including 114 major projects, must be undertaken to repair the damage.

Thomas Cook Airlines will operate a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer, using an Airbus A330 fleet. The airline introduced the service due to positive feedback from previous one-off flights to the US. The flight will operate from May 4th to October 31st, 2015, and Glasgow Airport welcomes the new route, citing it as excellent news for customers and a strengthening of their long-haul offering. Additionally, the airline has announced an extra flight to Tunisia, available three times a week during the summer of 2015.

England, Wales, and Northern Ireland are in pot one for the Euro 2016 draw, while the Republic of Ireland could be in pot three or four depending on play-off results. The seedings are based on Uefa's national team coefficient rankings. Potential groups include England, Italy, the Czech Republic, and Wales or Northern Ireland. The play-off draw is on Sunday, with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary as seeds. The Republic of Ireland, Denmark, Norway, and Slovenia are possible opponents in the two-legged deciders. The finals draw takes place on December 12.

Damon Smith denies making or possessing an explosive substance with intent to endanger life, but admitted perpetrating a bomb hoax. He built a device with ball bearings to make it look like a real bomb and intended to stop the train and get attention. The device was found by passengers and handed to a driver, who realized it contained wires and reported it. Smith has Asperger's syndrome and is interested in weapons. He started a timing mechanism on the device while changing trains and searched for news articles on the incident later. The trial continues.

The Mansfield District Council approved the £250m Lindhurst scheme, which includes 1,700 homes, a school, cemetery, community center, and park, despite 140 objections. The planning committee voted 5-5, with the chairman's casting vote in favor. Developers promise 4,000 jobs, but opponents raise concerns about countryside loss and congestion.
The UN reports that Europe has the highest rate of discarded fish, with 23% of catches being thrown back overboard, often dead, due to being the wrong species or undersized.

HP acquired Palm in 2011 for $1.2 billion, gaining the WebOS operating system. LG recently acquired WebOS from HP, planning to use it in smart TVs. The deal includes source code, engineers, documentation, and websites. HP retains underlying patents and technology for web-based services. The acquisition may herald a return to WebOS's smartphone roots and aligns with LG's need for easier-to-use gadgets.

Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy was left fuming after his team conceded a late goal to draw 1-1 with U's in a pre-season friendly. McCarthy criticized his team for poor defending and pointed to similar instances last season where they dropped points from winning positions late in the game. Despite not being bothered about pre-season friendlies, McCarthy was unhappy with the manner in which they conceded the goal.

Jane Austen's sight deteriorated significantly, according to tests on three pairs of her glasses at the British Library. Heavy metal poisoning from medication she took for rheumatism may have contributed to her early death. The glasses, which increased in strength over time, suggest she would have struggled to read or write towards the end of her life.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced a plan to fix Easter's date, currently variable due to the moon's cycle, to the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, following a meeting with Anglican Communion primates. This change, which has been attempted 15 times since the 10th century, aims to unify the date across Christian denominations and governments. The archbishop hopes for a change within 5-10 years, though it may take longer.

Ulster Bank's monthly survey of firms in Northern Ireland showed a modest decline in business conditions in April, with output and new orders decreasing. Manufacturing was a bright spot, with growth in output and new orders. Retail and construction sectors saw significant declines. Despite this, employment levels rose at the fastest rate in seven months. The future impact of the new Conservative government's policies on the economy is uncertain.

UKIP's high street shop in Penarth, Wales has faced opposition since its November opening. The party has invited "anarchist friends" to target posters of Nigel Farage and John Rees-Evans with eggs, but no eggs have been thrown yet, according to a UKIP spokesman.

The Theatre Royal in Windsor, UK, was forced to evacuate during the opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors" due to flash flooding. The auditorium was dried out and the show resumed the following night. The flood was caused by heavy rainfall, which also affected London, and was an unusual occurrence for the 100-year-old theatre.

Fiji, a country with a population of 876,000, has experienced political upheaval since its independence from Britain in 1970, largely due to tensions between the indigenous Fijian and ethnic Indian communities. Frank Bainimarama, a former military leader, was sworn in as prime minister in 2014, eight years after seizing power in a coup. The country has a diverse culture, with English, Fijian, and Hindi being major languages, and Christianity, Hinduism, and Islam being major religions. The president, Jioji Konousi Konrote, was elected in 2015 and is the first non-indigenous president. The government controls the media industry through the Media Decree, which has led to self-censorship. Key dates in Fiji's history include its independence in 1970, coups in 1987 and 2000, and the election of Frank Bainimarama as prime minister in 2014.

In Bihar, India, a student's comment that political science is about cooking went viral, leading to an investigation into cheating in the state's school exams. The government had implemented measures to curb cheating, but the results were still questionable. The pass rate was low, and two students who excelled in the exams, Ruby Rai and Saurabh Shrestha, were found to have cheated. They, along with 12 others, will have to retake a written test and interview with subject experts to verify their answers.

Protesters had been living in tents on St Peter's Square since April 15th, but Manchester City Council issued a warrant to close the camp and the demonstrators lost their appeal. The protesters have now relocated to St Anne's Square, about half a mile away. Police and bailiffs arrived at 8 am to break up the camp, and while some protesters left peacefully, others resisted. The campaigners aim to bring attention to the lack of temporary housing and the struggles of homeless people. The council claims that some protesters have behaved inappropriately in public, citing offensive graffiti, vandalism, fighting, public urination, street drinking, litter, and loud music. The camp has cost the council and police over £88,000 in additional costs, and the homelessness service has provided support and advice to over 20 members of the camp.

Two pieces of debris believed to be from MH370 were found in Mozambique and identified as consistent with panels from a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 aircraft. The discovery supports the theory that the missing plane went down in the Indian Ocean. The search continues, with 25,000 sq km still to be scanned, but may end in the coming months without significant new evidence.

The RMT union is planning two more days of strike action against ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour urges the transport minister to meet with both sides to end the stalemate. Transport Scotland says the minister has already engaged with both sides, while the RMT opposes driver-only trains and wants guards to control doors for safety. ScotRail claims 59% of customers already travel on trains with safely opened and closed doors by drivers, and a second person will always be on board to help customers. Transport Scotland calls for both parties to find a solution through meaningful discussion.

The Cavaliers lost the first two games of the series, but Kyrie Irving's 30 points helped them win Game 3 against the Warriors. Despite Steph Curry's 19 points, Golden State suffered a defeat. The Cavaliers will look to even the series in Game 4 on Friday.

The Official Charts Company announced that Ellie Goulding's song "Burn" has reached number one on the UK singles chart, selling 117,000 copies and outselling its closest rival, Avicii's "Wake Me Up," by 40,000 copies. Lady Gaga's "Applause" entered the chart at number five, while Miley Cyrus's "We Can't Stop" fell two places to number three. Goulding's previous highest charting single was her cover of Elton John's "Your Song," which peaked at number two in 2010. "Burn" features on the deluxe edition of Goulding's album "Halcyon," which climbed seven places in the album chart to number 19. The singer expressed her excitement about reaching number one, stating that it has always been her dream to have a UK number one single.

Highland Council has avoided £1.3m in planned cuts, but will still make savings through changes to sickness absence policy and schools energy incentives. A proposal to cut senior councillors' pay was defeated, and the council will not cut funding to services supporting vulnerable people. The council will still face challenges in setting a balanced budget due to the council tax freeze.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn read a Bible passage at a prison worship service that included verses condemning homosexuality. He was told that gay prisoners had complained, and he was later barred from leading worship services and eventually resigned due to alleged harassment over his Christian beliefs. He is now suing the secretary of state for justice, claiming unfair dismissal.

The Home Office must improve its handling of "overstayers" (foreign nationals refused leave to stay in the UK), according to the independent inspector of immigration. John Vine found that the Home Office's contract with Capita to review and close records of migrants had significant inaccuracies, leading to an overestimation of the number of "overstayers" who had departed. Vine called for improvements in the Home Office's monitoring and prioritization of immigration enforcement cases. Immigration Minister James Brokenshire agreed to implement the report's recommendations but emphasized that recent government changes have had a positive impact.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will close due to a lack of permanent dentists, leaving the town's other private practice as the only option. The NHS practice has been unable to recruit a permanent dentist for two years, and the deputy mayor of Dolgellau has called for more action to address the issue in rural areas. The health board plans to re-commission dental services but expects a gap in service during the tender process. Temporary solutions include short-term support from nearby practices and an out-of-hours clinic at the community hospital. The Welsh Government has emphasized the importance of ensuring NHS primary care dental services are available and has invited applications from dental contractors to help address the issue.

Liam Day, 26, went missing while climbing near Durlston Country Park in Southampton. An extensive search by police, coastguard, and rescue teams began Wednesday, but has now been suspended. Liam's partner, Emily Brown, believes he will not return. Climbing equipment was found west of Anvil Point. Police are still investigating and ask anyone with information to come forward.

McGuinness must develop a strategy to counter the defending champions' attacking style in the All-Ireland semi-final. He trusts his players to execute their roles and make decisions on the field. Despite being ranked as underdogs, McGuinness is focused on preparing his team and has faith in their abilities.

According to a report by High Fliers, 1,000 graduates declined job offers in 2015, leaving employers searching for replacements. 20,000 students were recruited, mostly at the start of their final year, giving them time to consider other options. Martin Birchall, Managing Director of High Fliers, stated that top employers are competing for the best candidates, with many receiving multiple offers. The number of graduates hired increased by 3.3% in 2015, with starting salaries remaining at around £30,000. However, graduate pay at top law firms, investment banks, and accounting firms increased further.

A man was injured when he fell onto the tracks at Twickenham Station after England's World Cup game. He suffered head and leg injuries and was taken to the hospital. The train had been slowing down, and the exact circumstances of the incident are still unclear. Services were temporarily suspended but have resumed.

Malta, located south of Sicily, has a rich history of colonial control, including the Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and French and British rule. It gained independence from Britain in 1964 and has since developed into a leading trading post and popular tourist destination. The country has a population of 419,000 and a diverse culture, with Maltese and English as major languages and Christianity as the primary religion. Malta has a president, Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, and a prime minister, Joseph Muscat, who have both been active in national politics for many years. The country has a long history of newspaper and radio broadcasting, with many outlets having strong political affiliations. Malta has faced challenges such as heavy bombing during World War II and has undergone significant changes since joining the European Union in 2004 and adopting the euro in 2008.

Demolition, a tragicomedy directed by Jean-Marc Vallee, premiered at TIFF. The film stars Jake Gyllenhaal as a successful investment banker who must rebuild his life after his wife's death. Vallee praised Gyllenhaal's performance, saying he "went everywhere" and "surprised me all the time." The film brings Vallee back to TIFF for a third consecutive year, following Dallas Buyers Club and Wild. Michael Moore's new film, Where to Invade Next, also premiered at the festival. TIFF traditionally marks the start of awards season, with past winners going on to win Oscars.

The Belfast Telegraph reports on a boy who survived a petrol bomb attack and is now battling a brain condition. His mother shares his story and the scars he received during the attack. The Irish News covers a controversial Stormont scheme that has awarded grants to Orange Halls, and a story about a County Tyrone boy fighting epilepsy in the US with the help of cannabis oil. The paper also reports on reactions to President Trump's travel ban and a prosecution decision on a suspect in the Kingsmills massacre.

Action on Hearing Loss surveyed 1,000 adults and found that 33% would ignore safe volume levels on their music players, increasing their risk of tinnitus. DJ Paul Oakenfold supports the campaign and urges people to wear ear defenders to gigs and use noise-cancelling headphones to protect their hearing. The poll also found that 1 in 10 people are affected by tinnitus, which can range from a light buzzing to a constant roar in the ears and head, and can impact concentration and sleep. The charity aims to raise awareness and fund research into treatments.

France won the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup, with Richard Gasquet and Coco Vandeweghe winning their respective matches. The United States tied the score with a win in the women's match, but France ultimately triumphed in the deciding doubles match. This is France's second title in the competition, following their 2014 victory. Great Britain did not advance past the group phase.

Australia's coach, Eddie Jones, discusses the upcoming match against Ireland at Twickenham, mentioning the long-standing rivalry between the teams. He also talks about Manu Tuilagi's future in the 12 shirt and how he sees him as an outstanding player. England is currently level with France at the top of the Six Nations table, and Jones praises his team's commitment and independence. He also expects Ireland to use an aerial bombardment strategy, which has been successful for them in the past.

In Scotland, paramedics treated over 12,000 people who were extremely drunk, according to a six-month report. The Scottish Ambulance Service stated that alcohol significantly impacts their operations. The NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde had the most alcohol-related 999 call-outs, followed by NHS Lothian and NHS Lanarkshire. Jackson Carlaw, Tory health spokesman, believes that personal responsibility is key to reducing alcohol-related incidents. The Scottish Ambulance Service wants the public to drink responsibly to avoid putting unnecessary pressure on their services. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt agrees, emphasizing the importance of responsible drinking to keep everyone safe.

The "Enabling Success" strategy has been launched in Northern Ireland to address economic inactivity, which affects 27% of the population, higher than the UK average. The strategy, launched by Employment Minister Stephen Farry and Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster, aims to increase employment levels to above the UK average by 2030 through 11 projects targeting individuals with work-limiting health conditions, lone parents, and carers. The strategy seeks to provide support for those who can work with the right assistance, increase economic competitiveness, and productivity in the global market.

Trump criticized McCain, saying he was only considered a hero because he was a prisoner of war. He later clarified his remarks, but did not apologize. McCain's daughter Meghan tweeted that she was disgusted, and many of Trump's rivals for the nomination attacked him. Trump has led in some early polls, but analysts predict his appeal will wane.

W.P. Kinsella, a renowned Canadian author, passed away on Friday through doctor-assisted suicide, a legal practice in Canada. Kinsella was best known for his novel "Shoeless Joe," which was adapted into the film "Field of Dreams." He published over 30 works across various genres and received the Order of Canada. After a head injury, he lost interest in writing fiction but later resumed and his final work is set to be released next year.

Máiría Cahill, a former IRA abuse victim, won a by-election in Ireland's Senate, securing 122 out of 188 votes. She apologized for her past involvement with a dissident republican group and pledged to use her position to support abuse victims and young jobseekers.

ChildLine has launched a campaign to address the concern of 12 to 13-year-olds who feel they are addicted to pornography. Boys in Cardiff and Prestatyn have contacted the charity, expressing worry about their exposure to pornography and its impact on their views of girls and relationships. A UK-wide poll found that one in five children have seen disturbing pornographic images. The charity emphasizes the need for open conversation and support to address this issue.

Mariner Street car park will be replaced with a 725-bedroom student block, including a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. The 22-storey tower, the second tallest in Swansea, is expected to be completed by summer 2018. The project aims to address the growing need for student accommodation and support the regeneration of High Street.

Torrential rain and flooding in Queensland and New South Wales, Australia, have caused damage and displacement. Several rivers have broken their banks, and residents have been evacuated. The storm has moved out to sea, but the damage bill is still unknown.

American Airlines experienced a software glitch on their iPads used by pilots and co-pilots for viewing flight plans, causing some flights to return to the gate for a wi-fi connection to fix the issue. The airline apologized for the inconvenience and is investigating the cause. The use of iPads and electronic flight bags is becoming more common among airlines to save fuel and reduce flight preparation time, with real-time updates and reduced likelihood of injuries.

Girish Pote was convicted for the 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak. He killed her and chopped her body into pieces. The crime was discovered when he confessed to relatives, who informed the police. Pote was given a life sentence, which will last for 14 years, but the judge said he would remain in jail for as long as he lived due to the gruesome nature of the crime.

Bradford Council plans to implement a clockwise one-way gyratory system on East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to alleviate growing congestion. The plans will be displayed at the Airedale shopping centre on June 11 and 13 for public viewing.

Thorpe, 23, has made 7 appearances for the Millers this season but hasn't played since the 5-2 loss to Ipswich on Nov. 7. He could make his Bradford debut against Millwall on Saturday, as the Bantams are currently 7th in League One, just outside the play-offs on goal difference.

A radio presenter pretended to be Carles Puigdemont and called Mariano Rajoy's office, where they were transferred to the PM and spoke with a Puigdemont impersonator. Rajoy agreed to meet with the fake leader and was later disappointed to learn it was a prank call. This incident highlights the tension between Rajoy and Puigdemont over Catalonia's future, with Rajoy pledging to maintain national unity and Puigdemont seeking secession. The prank call is not an isolated incident, as other high-profile leaders like Tony Blair and Fidel Castro have also fallen for similar jokes.

Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee questioned the £1 pay rate for immigration detainees who have committed no crime. Baroness Williams of Trafford defended the rate, saying it was voluntary and helped meet recreational and intellectual needs. Labour frontbencher Lord Rosser argued that the government saves £300,000 a month by using detainees at £1 an hour instead of minimum wage employees. Baroness Williams insisted the work was not about supplementing contractors and that the detainees benefit from the paid activities. The rate is being reviewed and a report is expected at the end of the year.

The Walter Scott Prize shortlist has been announced, featuring seven novels that offer readers a unique perspective on historical events. The judges praised the variety of the longlist and the way the shortlisted novels encapsulate moments in history in unforgettable ways. The winner will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in June.

Bangladesh need 33 runs to win their first Test against England, but have only two wickets left. England's Stuart Broad said the game has been exciting and both teams have shown skill, with the hosts' debutant Sabbir Rahman unbeaten on 59. The game has seen a record number of review decisions, with 24 so far. England are hoping for reverse swing to help them take wickets in the morning, and the series concludes with the second Test in Mirpur on Friday.

UCU Scotland members voted to strike over job security concerns at the University of Aberdeen's medical school. The union claims the process has been discriminatory as all four staff members affected are of Asian ethnic origin. The university denies this and says alternative employment has been offered to the staff members, rendering compulsory redundancies unnecessary. The university is disappointed by the strike action and will ensure exams are not disrupted.

Jay Liptrot, 43, owned the Prestatyn property where 5 people died in a fire in 2012. Lee-Ann Shiers, her partner, son, nephew, and niece died in the fire. Melanie Smith was jailed for 30 years for starting the fire. Liptrot will appear in court in May.
A 34-year-old man was arrested and later freed from custody pending further inquiries after a disgraceful incident at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay, according to Police Scotland.

The "Read On. Get On." report highlights the importance of children's reading skills, stating that those who fall behind may face negative consequences throughout their lives. A coalition of organizations, including Save the Children and the Scottish Book Trust, aims to improve reading skills among 11-year-olds. The report notes that families in lower income brackets have fewer children's books at home and that fathers in these households are less likely to read with their children. The coalition seeks to address this issue by encouraging parents and volunteers to help teach children to read. The report also mentions that while children still read books, they are increasingly reading text messages and online content.

The Belfast Giants have re-signed 30-year-old forward Martinelli for another season, while 28-year-old defenseman Garside has committed to an eighth season with the club. Both players have a history of success with the Giants, winning league championships and international titles. Head Coach Adam Keefe is excited to have them back and is looking forward to their contributions in the upcoming season.
Rasmus Barlow, 16, was reported missing and later found dead, with police stating that his death is not suspicious. The family is being supported by liaison officers.

Regina Hungerford, a teacher, was found guilty of unacceptable conduct by the Education Workforce Council after she lost her temper and slammed a notebook on a student's desk. The council ruled that she had made physical contact with the student, which put at risk the public trust in the profession and fell short of the expected standards. Hungerford's lawyer argued that she had not intended to make contact with the student, but the panel found the case against her proven.

Big brands and celebrities are using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou to promote their products and services on Star Wars Day. Mark Hamill and his family posed for a special portrait, and Darth Vader joined in. Global brands are using the hashtag to sell products, while the British Museum is hosting an actual Star Wars exhibit. Theo Paphitis and Heathrow Airport have also joined in the fun, while some charities are using the hashtag to raise awareness. Produced by Paul Harrison.

A group of retired generals and admirals endorsed Donald Trump as commander-in-chief, citing his temperament and ability to strengthen the military. Trump has been criticized for his treatment of veterans and military families, but he has made support for the military a central issue in his campaign. Both Trump and Hillary Clinton will participate in a national security forum, where they will face questions from military service members.

The 21-year-old player joined the Tykes from QPR after their promotion to the Championship, but made only seven league appearances. He had a brief loan spell at Colchester, playing six times. He signed a one-year contract with a 12-month option at John McGreal's team.

The Book of Dust, a new trilogy by Phillip Pullman, will be released starting in October 2017. The series will follow the story of Lyra Belacqua from infancy to age 20. Pullman's previous trilogy, His Dark Materials, sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

The American Red Cross apologized for a racist poster they produced that depicted black children as "not cool" for not following pool rules, while white children were shown behaving sensibly. The poster has been removed from their website and will no longer be printed. The organization committed to diversity and inclusion in all their activities.

Winkelman, the chairman of Milton Keynes Dons, expressed his support for manager Karl Robinson, stating that he will be the manager next season due to his drive and understanding of the club. Despite the team's relegation from the Championship, Winkelman believes Robinson is the right person for the job and is excited about the club's future in League One.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan have been named honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Cosmo has starred in films such as Braveheart, while Gillan has turned to directing after her role as Dr Who. EIFF artistic director Mark Adams is thrilled to have them on board, and both Cosmo and Gillan express their excitement and honor at being part of the festival.

Danny Rose, a left-back for Tottenham, recently made comments in an interview expressing his feelings of underpayment and the need for the team to sign well-known players. His comments were met with forgiveness from manager Mauricio Pochettino, who emphasized that Rose has a future at Tottenham. The team has not signed any players this summer and sold right-back Kyle Walker to Manchester City. Rose apologized for his words and will miss the game against Newcastle due to a knee problem.

Vanessa Vanakorn, a British violinist who competed for Thailand in the Sochi Winter Olympics, was banned from skiing for two years by the International Ski Federation (FIS) for allegedly manipulating results to ensure her qualification. She and five officials were punished following an investigation into four Slovenian races. Vanakorn has appealed the decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which will now consider her case.
Macclesfield Town defeated Eastleigh 1-0. Rhys Browne scored the only goal in the 7th minute. The game had chances for both sides, but Macclesfield's lead held.

Warner Bros TV is struggling to reach an agreement with the main cast of The Big Bang Theory over salaries. The cast, including Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Simon Helberg, and Kunal Nayyar, are seeking higher pay, potentially up to $1 million per episode. If new deals are not reached in the next two weeks, production may be delayed. Despite this, the cast is expected to return to work, and the show will continue to air until at least 2017. The actors' current salaries are $325,000 per episode, and they are seeking a significant increase.

Alexander Worth died in a car crash on an access road in North Warnborough. Matthew Cobden, 38, was injured and taken to hospital. Cobden appeared in court and was given unconditional bail. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court.

Refugees spoke at a gathering on Queen Street, calling for action. The Welsh Refugee Council's Hannah Wharf welcomed the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians. Demonstrations were held in Swansea and Caernarfon. Winter is approaching for refugees in camps neighboring Syria. The UK will accept up to 20,000 people from these camps, prioritizing vulnerable children. A Wales summit on the refugee crisis will be held next week. Local authorities are willing to help but need assistance with costs.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, a former hitman for Pablo Escobar, was released from prison after 20 years, having confessed to 300 murders and claiming involvement in 3,000 more. His release is controversial, with some arguing he hasn't paid for all his crimes, while others believe he deserves a second chance. Velasquez turned state's witness against a former justice minister convicted of ordering a presidential candidate's murder.

Kurt Gidley, a rugby league player for the Warrington Wolves, wore a camera during a game to give viewers a unique perspective. The camera was removed at half-time due to technical issues, and Gidley's coach Tony Smith said it was not an excuse for the team's poor performance. Sky Sports, the broadcaster, will continue experimenting with the technology.

Police were called to a care home in Campbeltown, Scotland, where a 76-year-old woman was allegedly sexually assaulted. An 82-year-old man is under investigation and has been reported to the procurator fiscal. The Care Inspectorate is working closely with Police Scotland and monitoring the situation. Anyone with concerns can contact their helpline.

Des McDaid, a survivor of child abuse, shared his experiences with the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry. He was sent to Australia from Northern Ireland at the age of eight and was sexually abused by older boys, Christian Brothers, and a lay teacher. He emphasized the helplessness he felt and described the various institutions he was sent to. He also talked about tracing his mother and their reunion. The inquiry is examining child abuse in religious and state-run institutions in NI from 1922 to 1995.

Stan Wawrinka defeated Kyle Edmund 6-7 (2-7) 6-4 6-4 in the quarterfinals of the Chennai Open. Wawrinka will face Kei Nishikori in the semifinals, while Milos Raonic will play Grigor Dimitrov. Aljaz Bedene lost to Benoit Paire in the quarterfinals.

U2's 50-year-old musician was treated at a neurosurgery clinic in Munich and will recuperate in Ireland. The band's US tour date on June 3 has been postponed, and their Glastonbury appearance may be in doubt. Further information about the impact on other tour dates will be announced later. The band's manager, Paul McGuinness, apologized for inconveniencing fans and advised them to monitor the U2 website for updates. The 360 Degree tour was the world's most profitable in 2009, earning the band $109m.

A light aircraft crashed between Abergavenny and Raglan in Wales, injuring two passengers and the pilot, who were taken to hospital. Officials alerted air accident authorities, and firefighters contained a fuel leak from the aircraft, which had approximately 120 liters of fuel on board. The road was closed, and two fire engines were at the scene.

Angela Scott will become the new chief executive of Aberdeen City Council in July, replacing Valerie Watts. Scott is currently the council's director of corporate governance and has impressed in her role. She has been chosen for her financial expertise, drive, and leadership skills. The salary for the position will be Â£144,685. Scott is looking forward to working with elected members, colleagues, and key partners to deliver on the city's priorities.

Manchester United's Matteo Darmian is out for several weeks due to a dislocated shoulder, leaving the team with only two fit full-backs, Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love. Love made his debut during the Premier League game against Sunderland, while Borthwick-Jackson made his first-team debut in November. United's manager Louis van Gaal expressed concern about the team's lack of full-backs, joking that he may have to line up a 13-year-old player.

Kenneth Harper was convicted of sex crimes, assault, and reckless behavior, but his convictions for two rape charges were later quashed due to lack of evidence. He was given a three-year sentence for the remaining offenses. The defense argued that the evidence was based on mutual corroboration and there was a significant time gap between the two alleged offenses. The Crown claimed that there were compelling similarities between the offenses, but the court ultimately found that there was no sufficient evidence to link the two incidents.

Jim Broadbent is set to play Tommy Butler in The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale, a drama that follows the investigation into the infamous heist. Broadbent is excited to play the role of the "fascinating copper" who led the investigation and notes that the drama will provide a unique perspective on the event. The actor has a strong track record, having won an Oscar and Bafta for previous roles.

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was attacked by a group of 20-25 girls in Central Park, Peterborough. The victim's mother posted a video of the brawl on Facebook to find the perpetrators. The police are investigating and the victim said the group wanted to fight her because they thought she was "being cheeky" at school.

The Maccabees scored their first number one album with "Marks To Prove It," narrowly beating Lianne La Havas' "Blood" by just 1,300 combined chart sales. Cilla Black's music saw a surge in popularity following her death, with "The Very Best of Cilla Black" reaching its highest ever chart position at number 14 and her single "Anyone Who Had A Heart" entering the singles chart at number 41. One Direction's new single "Drag Me Down" debuted at number two, while Calvin Harris and Disciples' "How Deep Is Your Love" climbed to number two and last week's number one, "Black Magic" by Little Mix, fell to three. The top five was rounded off with Lost Frequencies' "Are You With Me" at four and Years & Years' "Shine" at five.

One Direction continues as a four-piece band after Zayn Malik's departure. Liam Payne thanked fans for their support and emphasized that the band is not breaking up. They continue their tour, starting with Cardiff's Millennium Stadium. Zayn Malik quit due to stress and is working on a solo album with producer Naughty Boy.

Police Scotland is investigating a leak of sensitive information on social media, including witnesses' names and details of an alleged gun hit. Inquiries are ongoing to determine the full circumstances surrounding the incident.

Steven Flynn broke into St Johnstone's stadium with a crowbar to find money for drug debts. Police arrived after an alarm went off but didn't realize there had been a break-in. A cleaner found rummaged cupboards and a stolen charity box containing £20. Flynn was jailed for 16 months.

Nigel Farage visited Sleaford to support UKIP candidate Victoria Ayling in the upcoming by-election. A poster with a spelling error was noticed, and people joked about it on social media. The BBC contacted UKIP but received no response. The by-election takes place on Thursday.

Blair Henderson scored for the hosts 24 seconds in, finishing Michael McKenna's cross. Despite a near miss from Moses Olanrewaju, the hosts remained ahead. Brian Martin was later sent off for handling in the area, but the hosts still couldn't equalise as Sean Dickson missed a penalty.

Fiona Barnes was jailed for 15 months for stealing £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre and attempting to cover her tracks by faking documents. She was ordered to pay back £1 at a Proceeds of Crime hearing, which the centre's deputy manager, Jane Robinson, described as "outrageous" and a "complete insult". The centre, which supports children with disabilities, was nearly ruined by Barnes' actions.

Adam El-Abd, a 31-year-old defender, has joined Shrewsbury Town after being released by Bristol City. He has extensive experience, having played over 300 games for Brighton and having loan spells with several clubs. He joins Joe Riley, another former Bury player, as part of Micky Mellon's squad rebuilding effort for the new League One campaign.

Jones believes England needs 8-9 leaders to win the World Cup. He thinks society's changes affect player development. England is working on individual leadership plans. Hartley will captain the side, with Farrell as a potential replacement.

Somerset has signed Chris Rogers, a former Australian Test cricketer, to play in next season's County Championship. The 38-year-old left-hander will bat at three and provide stability to the side, supporting openers Marcus Trescothick and Tom Abell. Rogers has a wealth of experience and is known for his determination and athleticism. The team is looking forward to working with him and hopes his presence will help develop the younger players.

A Range Rover crashed into a house on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire, causing significant damage and displacing two people. No one was injured, but an investigation has begun and police are seeking witnesses. The front wall of the house was destroyed, and the road was closed for an hour.

Work to demolish a building on Kingsway began in October 2015, but the outer structure remains due to unexpected amounts of asbestos. The council plans to transform the area into a business district. Internal works are complete, and scaffolding is in place for exterior demolition. The project is expected to finish by spring.

Blackpool manager Gary Bowyer has called for the introduction of goal-line technology in the Championship after a controversial goal was awarded against his team during a 2-1 loss to Fulham. Bowyer believes the technology is necessary to ensure fairness in the game, especially given the high stakes of promotion and relegation in the Championship.

Leicester City have signed 19-year-old player Bartosz Kapustka for £7.5m on a five-year deal. He impressed at Euro 2016 and has joined the team in Stockholm before their friendly match against Barcelona. This is City manager Claudio Ranieri's fifth summer signing.

The Burrell Collection will temporarily close for redevelopment, reopening in 2020 with updated facilities and increased exhibition space. This weekend, the museum offers free activities before closing for renovations. The collection, donated in 1944, is currently only partially displayed due to concerns about damage. The refurbishment will energy-efficiently upgrade the building, add two new floors of exhibition space, and allow 90% of the 8,000 objects to be viewed by the public. During the closure, some works from the collection will be displayed at Kelvingrove Museum and Art Gallery in Glasgow, starting with an exhibition of 23 paintings by Joseph Crawhall.

Hundreds of farmers supplying chickens to Moy Park are recipients of the heating subsidy. The company met with officials to find a solution to secure the Northern Ireland RHI scheme within budget. Moy Park advocates responsible heat use and has extensive experience in benchmarked energy use in the poultry industry. The Finance Minister has raised concerns over the scheme's operation, but the company has not referenced any concerns. Cost control proposals were submitted and withdrawn. The Finance Minister is not interested in a botched solution to the RHI scandal.
A man's body was found in a field near Belsyde Avenue on Saturday. Police are investigating to identify the man and determine his cause of death through a post-mortem examination.
